awd_titl_txt: Statewide effort to diversify undergraduate engineering student population.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to investigate a framework that reassesses admissions criteria to deemphasize standardized tests by considering a holistic perspective of a student's academic experience. Research shows that putting too much weight on standardized tests results in a misrepresentation of a student's actual potential for academic success. Students, particularly students of color and women, are often negatively impacted by stereotype threat which has been shown to result in lower test scores. Therefore, test scores do not accurately reflect a student's ability.

To broaden participation in engineering, the College of Engineering at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln is broadening the admission review process to deemphasize standardized test scores and include a wider array of academic and social indicators. The changing demographics of Nebraska's high school graduates, and in particular the growth of the Hispanic/Latino/a population, make University of Nebraska-Lincoln an ideal place to study the impact of these changes on retention and graduation and the efficacy of subsequent student support programs for these students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to implement interventions to broaden participation in undergraduate engineering, computing and construction programs and to investigate their efficacy.  The project was motivated by several realities including the changing demographics of high school graduates, in particular the growth of the Hispanic/Latino/a population in the state of Nebraska, and the increasing body of research that shows that traditional measures of academic preparedness, e.g., standardized tests, are not accurate predictors of academic success for diverse and underrepresented students.  As part of this project, the College of Engineering at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln broadened the admission review process to deemphasize student test scores and to include a wider array of academic and social indicators in order to recruit more diverse students into engineering while implementing a variety of support programs to help these students succeed.

Over the course of the project, 143 students participated in three different pathway programs.  The Pathway for Engineering Achievement & Knowledge (PEAK) program engaged 29 students, the Women in Engineering (WIE) program engaged 59 students, and the Multicultural Engineering Program (MEP) engaged 55 students.  A rigorous mixed-method study, demonstrated that, on average, students who participated in these programs and received the various supports provided by these programs maintained a higher-grade point average and were retained in the college at a higher rate than students who did not participate in the programs.

Another important finding of this project is the important role that social capital and engineering capital play in student success.  Students enroll in college with varying levels of both and both are positively associated with engineering identity. Once students are on campus, they may have different access to capital based on their level of involvement in student support services and extracurricular activities. The project’s quantitative results support prior research that shows that higher social capital is associated with higher engineering identities which is, in turn, associated with engineering degree intentions.  Mentoring programs for women and racial/ethnic minorities provide access to formal and informal mentoring that increased social capital both directly and indirectly.

 

This project has demonstrated that support services that provide multiple types of mentoring increase social capital among underrepresented minority engineering students, and that high social capital is associated with high engineering identity that increases the likelihood to persist to earn an engineering degree. Programs aimed at increasing engineering student capital in the first semester of college should increase access to peer mentors and success coaching particularly for students who report families with less college-going capital.  This important outcome informs national efforts to meet the engineering, computing and construction workforce needs of the nation.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2023
Modified by: Patricia Wonch Hill
